title: Indicate that example is for CoAP
Clarify "body" terminology
Christer's editorial comments
body:
(https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/Yt_Un8MfppRi7hzJrVLiTJ1xcwQ)

**Q1**
 
The Introduction says talks about “request or response body’.
 
However, when looking in RFC 7252, I don’t find ‘body’ anywhere.
 
I assume that ‘body’ refers to what RFC 7252 calls ‘payload’. If so, I suggest aligning the terminology.
 
(For some reason section 10.2.3 of RFC 7252 does use ‘message-body’, without any explanation or reference, but I guess that is just an error)
 
**Q2**
 
Related to Q1, the text says:
 
   “can be used to combine representations of zero or more different media types into a single message”
 
I assume it means ‘single message payload’? Because, you are not combing other parts (Codes, Tokens etc) of the message, are you?
 
I think it would be more clear if you said ‘combine multiple representations, each using the same or different media types, into a single message payload’.
 
**Q3**

The draft uses both ‘media type’ and ‘media-type’. RFC 7252 uses ‘media type’ (there is one instance of ‘media-type’, though), so maybe align with that?

title: Multipart semantics
body: Address Benjamin Kaduk's outstanding DISCUSS.

Close Issue 10
Define fragment identifier syntax as in CBOR.
update affiliation
do not mention / suggest specific codepoint ranges

title: WGLC: Change ref to Observe to informative
body:
RFC7641 should be an informative reference as Observe seems to be referenced
only in the usage examples section.

title: WGLC: Change "Fragment identifier considerations" as CBOR's
body:
Carsten adds:
> Should we also copy the text: “(At
>     publication of this document, there is no fragment identification
>     syntax defined for “application/cbor”.)"
> ?

title: WGLC: Fix penultimate para of S3.2
body: Include one more byte for the CBOR array.

title: WGLC: Promote "Implementation hints" to top-level section
body: This doesn't seem like a usage example.  Promote it to a top-level section.

title: WGLC: The fate of the PubSub example
body:
Klaus:
> I see that draft-ietf-core-coap-pubsub-05 is still proposing a
> new response code (2.07) for this scenario. Will -pubsub switch to
> -multipart-ct as described in this section? If not, better remove the
> example.

title: WGLC: Remove note about future extensions providing the media type info in different ways
body:
```
(Future extensions might want to include additional alternative
ways of specifying the media type of a representation in such a
position.)
```
There is little a reader of the document could actually do with this
information.

title: WGLC: Say how a receiver handles syntactically invalid application/multipart-core representations
body:
Klaus:
> There should be a sub-section or paragraph specifying what a
> recipient of a application/multipart-core representation should do if
> it encounters something that doesn't match the grammar. Does the whole
> array become unusable when there is an unexpected element, or can a
> recipient use the array up to the unexpected element? Should a
> recipient try to do error recovery and skip to the next element? This
> has impact on how the format can be evolved in the future.

Carsten seems to prefer failing hard and early (draft-iab-protocol-maintenance).

Thomas loves simplicity and +1 Carsten's proposal.

title: WGLC: Say FCFS explicitly
body:
```
[...] typically one in the range 10000-64999
```

Klaus
> Better not to state the range explicitly as that locks the Content-Formats registry into providing this range for this purpose forever.

Carsten
> Should we say "First Come First Served" instead of 10000-64999?

title: WGLC: Applications need to stay within the CDDL
body:
```
[...] Applications using the application/multipart-core Content-Format
define the internal structure of the application/multipart-core
representation.
```
We should add something like: " within the syntactical boundaries defined by
the CDDL in Figure 1."

title: WGLC: Clarify "message-body"
body:
```
[...] into a single CoAP message-body with minimal framing overhead,
each along with a CoAP Content-Format identifier.
```
-> s/message-body/request or response body/

title: WGLC: "several (different media types)" is too restrictive
body:
```
[...] that can be used to combine representations of several different
media types
```
It should not preclude 0, 1 or 2, therefore: s/several/zero or more/

title: Fix numeric value of 2**16 (-1)
